posts.name: Eddie Patton
posts.cooked:
I’m a new mentor helping team 3268 with limit sensors. We are trying to incorporate limit sensors in stopping an arm from exceeding it’s movable range. We are using the REV info provided below and the breakout board to connect the limit switches, but what I’d like to know is what’s the best approach to have the software sense that the limit switch has hit it’s limit. For example, the sequence could be

SW starts lowering arm using Neo motor

arm hits limit sensor

??? notifies SW that the sensor is hit

SW reverses Neo motor

What would be the ??? that notifies software?

In the above steps, the HW is configured to have the Spark Max breakout board wired to the limit switches. Many thanks

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
It is possible to configure the limit switches such that the forward limit switch blocks forward output and the reverse limit switch blocks reverse output. I believe this is possible to set up with the Spark Max over USB without even touching code. From the documentation it looks like they are even enabled by default: image 785×356 25 KB

image 785×356 25 KB

image 785×356 25 KB

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
For limit switches, it’s very nice to wire them into the motor controller directly (or else have them on the CAN bus so the controller can see them without the rio being involved).  Even better, you can configure them so that if they get disconnected or a wire breaks, the motor will stop.

The first step is wiring them up.  For SPARK MAX, the next step is configuring the motor controller.  After that, test things out – ideally do this before you have the motor enabled (or mechanically disconnect it).

Do you have some kind of breakout for the data port?

posts.name: Eddie Patton
posts.cooked: Yes.  The HW is configured to have the Spark Max breakout board (inserted in the Data Port) wired to the limit switches. One of our SW programmers said we could use the NEO angle info to determine that it’s hit the limit switch. I’m not very sure how consistent that will be. My past experience with FLL rotation sensors wasn’t good.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked: I’m not a programmer, but couldn’t you just read the state of the limit switch? The relevant Java command is listed here: SparkLimitSwitch (FRC-REVLib API)

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
You may want the safety of a limit switch wired into the motor controller for an arm.  You can add soft stops or even regions where you limit the power as you approach the limit via code, but it’s very nice to know you won’t drive the arm into the mechanical stop and either stall the motor or break something.  And, the code can take time to work out, you may need to zero the position sensor or find the offset, etc.  (If you use the sensor in the NEO, the limit switch is also useful for zeroing things).

If you have the switch(es) wired up, you should be able to use the REV Hardware Client to see the status and apply settings to make these stop the motor.  You can burn these settings and not have to do anything at all in your code.  You can also read the status from your code (helpful for zeroing things).

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Limit switched hard wired into the SparkMax make you safe from most code-related “oopsie” events.  ONCE you get the polarity right, of course.  BUT, if they run into the limit switch at top speed, all your bets are off Ideally you want your limits to trip as the arm/object PASSES the switch, rather than smashes into the switch. Reed relays for alarm systems are a good trick for a magnetic based sensor that looks electrically like a switch.

posts.name: Eddie Patton
posts.cooked: Thanks everyone for the info. It’s really helpful. Here’s a good short tutorial on a Reed relay.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: One tip: don’t use fancy neodymium magnets with these.  Theres a real chance of permanently magnetizing them closed use cheapo ceramic magnets or, better yet, whatever came WITH them

posts.name: Eddie Patton
posts.cooked: I’d still like to know if there’s a way for SW to be notified that a limit switch event has occurred. It seems like there should be a way to interrupt the SW on a limit switch trigger. Otherwise, the SW has to pole the rotation sensor (or what ever sensor) to know when the limit sensor has been triggered.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: As far as I understand, the limit switch state is available on the CAD bus…

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
It looks as though limit switch status is not part of the periodic status frames .  This means you can best use these by setting the motor controller to directly act on the inputs.  If you want to also use them for something like zeroing position, calling the API to query them is appropriate.  But, this is going to involve round-trip CAN messaging.

If you just want a way to quickly/efficiently read a limit switch on the rio, wiring the limit switch the a DIO port is probably a better option.

If you want both aspects, without the round-trip CAN messaging, you can either use something that has two outputs (DPST switch) or, use two switches; one output or switch with the SPARK and one with the rio.
